data.title: China pauses rare earth curbs—brokerage says relief not yet here
data.description:
Breaking Beijing’s stranglehold on rare earths will remain a long-term challenge, with China expected to retain its strategic leverage over these critical minerals, Fitch's BMI said in a note on Friday.

China’s Ministry of Commerce on Oct. 30 suspended the export controls introduced on Oct. 9 for one year, following U.S.-China trade talks at the APEC summit. Miners, including MP Materials (MP), USA Rare Earth (USAR), TMC (TMC), Critical Metals (CRML), and Energy Fuels (UUUU) gained on Thursday following the deal.

The rare earth market has been on a roller coaster regulatory ride in 2025 thus far, with the October set of sweeping rare earth export restrictions from Mainland China marking a sharp escalation from previously introduced curbs in April 2025.

While a round of negotiations in London in June 2025 brought a temporary détente, resulting in the resumption of rare earth exports from China, a renewed wave of trade frictions rattled the market in early October.

"The much-anticipated de-escalation of trade tensions once again with the US-China deal on October 30 will likely deliver only short-term respite for market players, given Beijing’s commanding position" in the sector, which is poised to remain unrivalled in the short to medium term.

China’s dominance becomes even more acute along the value chain, with the country responsible for about 91% of global magnet rare earth output at the refining stage in 2024, according to the International Energy Agency.

While the US-China deal grants the West access to Mainland China's rare earths supply chain for now, this will depend on political temperature going forward, the brokerage added.

"The country’s entrenched capabilities in both mining and processing fields, well-established technological expertise and comparatively lower production costs will continue to underpin its dominant position," analysts noted. 

ETFs: (REMX), (LIT), (ILIT), (BATT), (URA), (NLR), (URNM)

data.title: Federal Reserve plans to cut banking supervision staff by 30% - report
data.description:
The Federal Reserve plans to reduce its banking supervision staff by about 30% by the end of this year, according to a Wall Street Journal report that cites an internal memo.

Vice Chair for Supervision Michelle Bowman announced a reorganization of the supervision and regulation division to shrink the unit from nearly 500 authorized positions to around 350 employees.

Bowman told staff she intends for the division to operate with fewer management layers, according to the report. “The goal is to accomplish this reduction as much as possible through natural attrition, retirements, and by offering a voluntary separation incentive to all S&R division employees, with details to come in the following weeks,” the memo read.

This move aligns with a broader Federal Reserve workforce reduction plan of around 10% over the next few years, which is also in line with the Trump administration's push to reduce regulatory burdens and federal staff levels.

ETFs to track the broader U.S. market: (NYSEARCA:SPY), (NYSEARCA:VOO), (NYSEARCA:IVV), (NYSEARCA:RSP), (NYSEARCA:SSO), (NYSEARCA:UPRO), (NYSEARCA:SH), (NYSEARCA:SDS), and (NYSEARCA:SPXU).

data.title: Nasdaq futures rise sharply as Amazon, Apple results bring cheer
data.description:
Stock index futures were higher on Friday, as Nasdaq futures led the charge, driven by strong earnings from tech companies. 

S&P 500 futures (SPX) +0.8%, Nasdaq 100 futures (US100:IND) +1.4%, and Dow futures (INDU) +0.1%.

Wall Street ended lower on Thursday after Meta ((META)) and Microsoft ((MSFT)) earnings failed to impress investors.

Results from tech companies helped cheer the mood and improve market sentiment. 

"Indeed, just as the tech mood had soured yesterday, this morning that has mostly turned around following results from Apple and Amazon after the closing bell," Deutsche Bank's Jim Reid said.

"This renewed momentum has helped sentiment after a more challenging day yesterday, despite the positive outcomes from the U.S.-China trade discussions. Investor concerns over AI-related capital expenditure resurfaced, highlighted by Meta’s sharp decline of 11.33% after results after the closing bell on Wednesday night," Reid added.

Amazon (AMZN) soared 11.9% in premarket trade after it crushed Q3 estimates with better-than-expected net sales, profits, and subscription revenues, and more importantly. It also delivered a beat on the company’s AWS, all of which offset compressed margins.

Apple (AAPL) was up 2.5% before the opening bell after the tech giant reported fiscal fourth-quarter results that topped estimates.

On political news, the U.S. States reportedly cancelled a planned Budapest summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin following Russia's firm stance on hardline demands regarding Ukraine. 

On the earnings front, Chevron (CVX) and ExxonMobil (NYSE:XOM) will report their results before the market opens.

data.title: Spain's Telefonica weighs plan to cut dividend - report
data.description:
• Telefónica SA (TEF) is set to cut its dividend as part of a new strategic plan due to be announced next week, Bloomberg News reported on Thursday.
  • The Spanish carrier has one of the highest dividend yields among European telecom operators, and its new policy aims to align it with peers, the report said. 
  • The change also seeks to strengthen the balance sheet, free cash for investments, and signal commitment to financial discipline.

data.title: France inflation expected to drop to 1%
data.description:
• The inflation rate in France decreased to 1% in October from 1.20% in September, lower than estimates of 1.1%, the preliminary data showed.

  • The Consumer Price Index increased 0.10% in October over the previous month.

  • ETFs: (NYSEARCA:EWQ)

  • Currency: (EUR:USD)

data.title: Toyota supplier Denso drops as it cuts outlook on FX, quality costs
Columbia Banking System signals accelerated capital return with $700M buyback and targets $8B loan optimization amid Pac Premier integration
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Columbia Banking System, Inc. (COLB) Q3 2025

Management View

  • President and CEO Clint Stein emphasized the successful closing of the Pacific Premier acquisition on August 31, noting, "This milestone completes our 8-state Western footprint and bolsters our position as the preeminent regional bank in the Northwest with approximately $68 billion in assets." Stein highlighted expanded market share and described the bank as uniquely positioned for organic growth in dynamic Western markets, with a sharpened focus on "optimization, generating new business, supporting the growing needs of existing customers and delivering superior results for all of our shareholders, even as we look to complete the integration of Pac Premier."

  • Stein outlined a strategic shift toward organic growth, supported by a "disciplined cost-conscious culture" and a commitment to "generating positive economic impact." He also announced a management transition: "This will be Ron's last earnings call with Columbia as he is stepping down following a very successful tenure as our CFO." Ivan Seda was named as the new CFO.

  • CFO Ron Farnsworth stated, "We reported second quarter EPS of $0.40 and operating EPS of $0.85. Operating excludes merger and restructuring expense, along with other fair value and hedging items detailed in our non-GAAP disclosures, which I encourage you to review." Farnsworth highlighted that operating PPNR increased 12% from the second quarter to $270 million and discussed the $1.9 billion reduction in broker deposits and term debt during the quarter, which "drove net interest margin expansion." He also noted the realization of $48 million of the targeted $127 million in expected annualized cost savings as of September 30.

Outlook

  • Stein announced, "I'm pleased to announce our Board of Directors authorized a $700 million share repurchase program, reflecting our confidence in the strength of Columbia's balance sheet." He cited "roughly 110 basis points or approximately $550 million of excess capital above our long-term target today."

  • Management expects to "organically manage down roughly $8 billion of inherited transactional loans" over the next several years, with a focus on remixing the portfolio to drive profitability.

  • Seda indicated that the pace of share repurchases in the remainder of this year will be "modestly lower than the average quarter before we look to ramp it back up into 2026," dependent on market conditions.

  • Management expects "exceptional profitability, which will result in meaningful capital generation over the coming quarters."

Financial Results

  • Columbia reported operating EPS of $0.85 and operating PPNR of $270 million, reflecting 12% sequential growth. Net interest margin increased 9 basis points to 3.84%.

  • The company reduced broker deposits and term debt by $1.9 billion, contributing to margin expansion. Tangible book value per share rose to $18.57, and regulatory capital ratios expanded, with Tier 1 common at 11.6% and total risk-based capital ratio at 13.4%.

  • Noninterest income was $77 million for the quarter, with operating noninterest income at $72 million. Operating expense was $307 million, while $48 million of the planned $127 million in cost synergies from the Pacific Premier acquisition were achieved.

  • On the lending side, "New loan originations of $1.2 billion is up 36% quarter, while year-to-date volume is up 21% from last year." Organic commercial portfolio growth was 5% annualized.

Q&A

  • Christopher McGratty, KBW: Questioned the rationale and pacing for the $700 million buyback. Stein responded the program spans 12 months with flexibility for market conditions, and Seda clarified, "It's presumable that we could go through the entire authorization over the course of the next 12 months."

  • David Feaster, Raymond James: Asked about the recent activist investor presentation. Stein replied, "Our priorities in no particular order are consistent, repeatable top-tier quarterly performance... we've been focused on and preparing for additional capital returns... Pac Premier... was the missing piece to our franchise... I have 0 interest in M&A for the foreseeable future."

  • Jeff Rulis, D.A. Davidson: Inquired about loan growth outlook. Nixon replied, "New originations on the lending side are roughly between 6.5% and 8%. I think probably a weighted average this past quarter was in the low 7s." Nixon added, "5% annual loan growth... is definitely our target."

  • Matthew Clark, Piper Sandler: Asked about margin expectations. Seda projected net interest margin "just north of 3.90%" for Q4, with a similar range for Q1 2026.

  • Jared Shaw, Barclays: Queried about allowance levels and merger charges. Merrywell said allowance should "kind of a slow kind of upward migration," and Farnsworth confirmed merger cost expectations are "unchanged."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed management on the buyback pace, activist investor influence, loan growth, margin sustainability, and integration costs, reflecting a neutral to slightly positive but vigilant tone.

  • Management exhibited a confident tone during prepared remarks, especially regarding capital strength, profitability outlook, and integration of Pac Premier. In the Q&A, the tone remained confident and occasionally emphasized focus, with Stein stating, "I have 0 interest in M&A for the foreseeable future."

  • Compared to Q2, both analysts and management showed more direct focus on capital return, integration benefits, and organic growth, with management expressing increased confidence in the franchise's trajectory.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Management's strategic focus shifted from anticipation of the Pac Premier acquisition to post-integration execution, with a significant new focus on capital return through the $700 million buyback.

  • Capital ratios have increased from the previous quarter, and the tangible book value dilution from the acquisition came in well below initial expectations.

  • The prior quarter emphasized operational efficiency and preparation for acquisition, while this quarter highlighted realized cost synergies, expanded markets, and new capital allocation strategies.

  • Analyst questions have shifted from integration planning to execution, capital deployment, and sustainability of profitability amid balance sheet remixing.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited the need to "organically manage down roughly $8 billion of inherited transactional loans" as a critical ongoing process.

  • There is sensitivity to macroeconomic volatility, with share repurchase pacing subject to market conditions.

  • Integration of Pac Premier, while progressing, still involves ongoing system conversions and realization of full cost synergies.

  • Seasonality in deposits, potential deposit outflows, and the impact of interest rate movements were noted as factors to monitor.

Final Takeaway

Columbia Banking System underscored the completion and integration of the Pacific Premier acquisition as a catalyst for expanded market reach, enhanced profitability, and capital strength. The company launched a $700 million share repurchase program, signaling confidence in the franchise and prioritizing shareholder returns. Management remains focused on remixing the loan portfolio for higher earnings quality, prudent expense management, and disciplined organic growth, with no plans for further M&A. The outlook reflects strong capital generation, robust loan pipelines, and ongoing optimization to deliver long-term shareholder value.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: MediaTek Non-GAAP EPS of NT$16.18, revenue of NT$142.1B
data.description:

  • Revenue of NT$142.1B (+7.8% Y/Y).

data.title: Nvidia to send over 260,000 GPUs to South Korea
data.description:
South Korea's government has announced a wide-ranging collaboration with Nvidia to acquire over 260,000 of its most advanced AI GPUs, marking deployment in public and private sector.

"On October 31, the Ministry of Science and ICT announced that it would establish an ongoing partnership with Nvidia to secure AI infrastructure, strengthen physical AI capabilities, and support startups," The Asia Business Daily reported. 

Of these, ~50,000 GPUs will be rapidly supplied to the public sector, including the National AI Computing Center and the development of proprietary AI foundation models. Private companies like Samsung Electronics (OTCPK:SSNLF), SK (OTCPK:HXSCF), Hyundai Motor Group, and Naver will utilize over 200,000 GPUs to drive AI in manufacturing.

SK Group is talking with Nvidia (NVDA) ways to establish a 'Manufacturing AI Startup Alliance' and will set up Asia's first enterprise-led manufacturing AI cloud, the report added.

On the same day, Hyundai Motor Group, Nvidia (NVDA), and the Ministry of Science and ICT also signed an MoU to position Korea as a leader in physical AI.

"Just as Korea's physical factories have inspired the world with sophisticated ships, cars, chips and electronics, the nation can now produce intelligence as a new export that will drive global transformation," Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang commented, neither deal value nor supply schedule.

Nvidia (NVDA) did not immediately respond to Seeking Alpha's request or comment.
